tplan.name: Camera Hexapod Functional Re-Verification and Integration with SAL
tplan.objective:
The objective of this test plan is to re-verify the functional
requirements of the Camera Hexapod\textquotesingle s hardware and
software after shipment from the vendor\textquotesingle s facility to
the Summit, as defined in \citeds{LTS-206} and \citeds{LTS-160}.\\
This test campaign will only exercise the functionality that was
executed previously and meets the following criteria:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Requires the vendor\textquotesingle s EUI software and hardware via
  local control
\item
  Requires control via SAL
\item
  Requires a laser tracker, mechanical gauges, temperature sensors
\item
  The first test cycle does \textbf{NOT} require the camera rotator to
  be loaded with the camera simulated mass or actual camera hardware
\item
  The second test cycle requires the camera rotator to be loaded with
  ComCam
\item
  Does not require the CCW or Camera Rotator to be operable.
\end{itemize}

\hfill\break
The hardware and software functional requirements were previously
verified during the test campaign by the vendor at the
vendor\textquotesingle s facility and accepted by LSST during the
Factory Acceptance Test review.

custom_fields.Overall Assessment:
The following results are for the first test-cycle LVV-C114:
The camera hexapod was tested at Level 3 without a payload attached. Depending on the test case, the hexapod was controlled through the EUI or the CSC.
The overall assessment of the first test case execution was: One test case INITIAL PASS, and two test cases: FAIL.
After the third execution, all three test cases belonging to test cycle LVV-C114 of this test plan have the status: INITIAL PASS.

On the software side
  • the EUI was reorganized to reflect the association of the commands with the states of the state machine correctly (DM-29738)
  • the reaction of the state machine to the "clearError" command was improved (DM-29788)
  • some minor issues regarding rare events have easy workarounds. Therefore, the corresponding test steps passed with deviations.
    Specifically the inappropriate disconnection of the
    • encoder cable (DM-29791) 
    • power supplies (DM-29792) 
    • network connection (DM-29793).

The camera hexapod CSC software was improved by
  • including checks into the camera hexapod CSC for position limits for the move and offset commands (DM-23092)
  • cleaning up XML for rotator and hexapods (DM-21699)
  • Generating  the inPosition event in the EFD (DM-29689)
  • reporting the camera hexapod pivot point modifications in the EUI and the EFD (DM-29693)
  • correcting the transition of the camera hexapod's state machine back into standbyState (DM-29705)
  • accepting the Disable command accepted and changing the state machine status correctly (DM-29706)

The configuration part of the CSC test case (LVV-T1600) was not tested since the configuration system for all CSC is still under development. The hexapod acceleration and velocity changes are not done by stand-alone commands anymore and were, therefore, not tested. Since the state machine of the CSC is still under development and will change to a standbyState-entry state machine, the state machine transitions were only partially tested as needed to conduct the other tests.

At the beginning of this verification activity, the hardware of the camera hexapod presented issues in actuators 3 and 6. Both had dead encoder zones that made the hexapod stop immediately. Recovery needed direct intervention at the issue-causing actuator. The problem was solved by taking out all actuators and servicing them by cleaning the encoder band from Teflon and grease/oil and reassembling the hexapod. In addition, during the service, the cables to the encoders were found to be damaged due to the movements of the actuators. This triggered a redesign of the actuator heads that is currently ongoing. (see FRACAS-28 for the actuator 3 failure and FRACAS-54 for the actuator 6 failure).

Though not directly part of this verification testing, a random failure (a feedback fault in Drive 0 and Drive 2) caused significant delays during test execution. The encoders inside of the actuators as well as the drives themselves, were first suspected as the cause for the failure. The actuators could be excluded as the origin of the fault by exchanging the cabling between the actuators. The drives did not present any obvious failure reason. The issue was solved after finishing this test by exchanging the cables to one actuator and testing that this solution could be reproduced by changing the cable from between the drives. All cables were exchanged. The problem did not appear again.

Apart from the aforementioned issues, the camera hexapod did not reach the XYZ accuracy as required (LVV-19501) at the beginning of the testing campaign.
This hardware-related issue concerns the following requirements
  • LTS-206-REQ-0164-V-02: 3.5.12_1 Positioning - LSST Re-verification
  • LTS-206-REQ-0178-V-02: 3.5.24_1 Hexapod Absolute Accuracy - LSST Re-verification.
Specifically, the tests on the positioning in X, Y, and Z translation combined with rotation failed to reach the required precision. The same issue was observed for the hexapod's absolute accuracy. The reasons were lying, most likely in the measurement setup itself. The laser tracker measurements are at the limit of the laser tracker's precision, and the MITUTOYO gauges mounts were a preliminary solution. Testing the camera hexapod with an improved MITUTOYO setup has shown that the same requirements are fulfilled for the camera hexapod.

All executed hardware tests passed, as mentioned at the beginning of this summary. Some measurements for the range in Z direction and rotation around the Z-axis were given little priority since they are testing a movement that is not expected to be used during normal operations and were not performed due to missing time reasons.

The following results are for the second test-cycle LVV-C191:
  • The main difference for this test cycle consists of ComCam being attached to the rotator.
  • All executed hardware tests passed again. Some measurements for the rotation around the Z-axis were given little priority since they are testing a movement that is not expected to be used during normal operations and were not performed due to missing time reasons.
  • The test case for the Camera Hexapod Hardware Functional Re-verification (LVV-T1598 (1.0)) has passed.
  • The LVV-T1599 Camera Hexapod Software Functional Re-verification test case was most successfully executed in the previous test cycle. Only one command was missing to be tested for the EUI. This test was successfully completed. Several requirements considering the telemetry and the Lookup Tables (LUTs) need to be tested together with the CSC (compensation mode) and were moved to the SAL test case LVV-T1600.
custom_fields.Recommended Improvements:
The following recommendations are for the situation after the first test-cycle LVV-C114:
  • To improve the situation before the next test cycle, it is recommended to finish the development of the camera hexapod low-level controller, the EUI, and the CSC.
  • The EUI and CSC software tests regarding the state machine should be executed when the state machine is updated to the standbyState-entry state machine. Beforehand, the test cases should be updated to account for state machine tests.
  • The configuration part of the CSC test case (LVV-T1600) should be updated to account for the change in accordance with LSE-209 and need to be tested for the first time.
  • The camera hexapod acceleration and velocity changes should now be tested as part of the configuration tests.
  • For the hardware tests, the camera hexapod should always be tested starting from the origin to avoid possible hysteresis.
  • Each test step to measure the absolute accuracy of the camera hexapod should be repeated at least three times to ensure the accuracy of the test results.
  • The following hardware tests from the MOOG testing sequence should be included
    • 3.3.10 Hexapod Rotational Rz range
    • 3.3.1  Only the hexapod positioning in Rz. The rest was tested and is within specification.
    • 3.3.13 Measure Rz

The following recommendations are for the situation after the second test-cycle LVV-C191:
  • The hardware-related tests need to be re-executed when the redesign and reconstruction of the actuator are finished.
  • This involves new hardware and is, therefore, not part of this test plan for re-verifying the vendor-delivered hardware.
  • During the test with the new hardware, including a test over the full range up to the software limits. It must include the +/- 8.7mm position.
custom_fields.System Overview: The Camera Hexapod is mounted to the Camera Rotator with the primary function of aligning the camera with the optical path of the telescope.
custom_fields.Verification Environment: The Camera Hexapod will be verified in a climate-controlled environment on the 3rd floor of the Summit Facility integrated with the Camera Cable Wrap on the Camera Cart.
custom_fields.Exit Criteria:
In order for this event to be considered complete, the following criteria must be met:
  • Raw test data, events, and telemetry have been saved for the Camera Hexapod.
  • All test data has been analyzed and post-processed.
  • All test steps have been statused in the Jira Test Cases within this Test Plan, and actual results populated as required.
  • A summary of the results of the test campaign has been captured in the Overall Assessment and Recommended Improvements fields of this Test Plan.
  • A link to the verification artifacts used to produce the summary of results has been populated in the Verification Artifacts field of this Test Plan
  • Any failures have been captured in the FRACAS project.
custom_fields.Entry Criteria:
In order to test the Camera Hexapod functionality, the following criteria must be met first:
  • All the test setup for the Data Acquisition system must be completed and ready to record data for the laser tracker and inductive current probes
  • The Laser tracker and SMR's are installed and setup
  • The Inductive current probes are installed and setup
  • All utilities and electrical connections are hooked up and allow the Camera Hexapod to be powered on and controlled
  • The EFD must be set up to be able to store events and telemetry data

At the beginning of this verification activity, the hardware of the

script_results.description:
STARTING THE EUI

Double click the Hexapod GUI Viewer desktop icon on the computer.
  • This can be done on the Dell Management PC or another computer on the same network
script_results.expectedResult: A prompt to enter the password is shown.
script_results.actualResult: We saw the prompt window and was asked for the password.

script_results.description:
Enter the password "lsst-vnc"
  • If the EUI isn't automatically up and running when the VNC opens, double click on the Hexapod-eGUI icon on the VNC viewer
script_results.expectedResult: The EUI is in the Offline State/PublishOnly substate and is able to publish through SAL but cannot receive commands.
script_results.actualResult: After we entered the "lsst-vnc", we can log in the system. The initial state is Offline State/PublishOnly. We saw the green light of DDS connected.

script_results.description:
OFFLINESTATE/AVAILABLESTATE
On the Main tab, select the "Offline SubState Cmd" field in the Commands to Send section, set the Offline SubState Triggers to "System Ready" and click on the Send Command button.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from the OfflineState/PublishOnly substate to the OfflineState/AvailableState substate and the Command Source says eGUI.
script_results.actualResult: We transited the system to the OfflineState/AvailableState substate.

script_results.description:
OFFLINESTATE -> STANDBYSTATE
Click on the State Command field in the Commands to Send section.
script_results.expectedResult: The State Triggers dialogue box shown below becomes visible.
script_results.actualResult: We transited the system to the Standby state.

script_results.description: Scroll through the available trigger options to select "Enter Control" and click the Send Command button.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions to the Standby state and the primary state display box at the top of the Main says Standby State.
script_results.actualResult: We transited the system to the Standby state.

script_results.description:
STANDBYSTATE -> DISABLEDSTATE
From the StandbyState, send a Start State command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into DisabledState and the current configuration parameters are maintained from the default parameters or from the previous DDS start command.
script_results.actualResult: We transited the system to the Disabled state.

script_results.description:
DISABLEDSTATE -> ENABLEDSTATE
From the DisabledState, send an Enable State Command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the EnabledState/Stationary substate, the motor drives are enabled and and motion can be commanded.
script_results.actualResult: We transited the system to the Enabled state.

script_results.description:
<conditional state>
FAULTSTATE
If a Fault occurs in any of the other states, the system will automatically transition to the Fault State. While in the Fault state, send a clearError.
Note: If the fault that occurs goes through the interlock system, reset the safety relay switch and send a clearError command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions back to the OfflineState/PublishOnly substate. (Go back to Step 3)
script_results.actualResult:
For the safety interlock, press the E-stop first, click the switch button of release interlock 2, release the E-stop, click the switch button of reset interlock. By doing this, we could put/ release the safety interlock. No clearError in software side is needed.

When we opened the hexapod GUI, there was the simulink error after hitting the systemReady command and entered the Fault state. We can use the clearError to leave the Fault state and do the state transitions.

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.1 Positioning of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 23-24.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Test this with no performance payload and at a single elevation angle of zero degrees.
script_results.expectedResult: The position of the hexapod is able to be commanded and no software limits or limit switches are tripped.
script_results.actualResult:
Measurements for the positioning could not be completed due to a failure in drive #3.
1) The tilt angle, tilt offset distance and pivot distance are all OK, but once reached, the X and Zdon't seem to be able to reach position to within ~2mm
2) Laser tracker seems to contradict MOOG's statement about corners representing different combinations of the maximum simultaneous range requirements for X and Z

Test failed, see detailed results from the laser tracking measurement done by Roberto Tighe and Mario Rivera.
The error needs to be interpreted as: sqrt( (errX^2) + (errY^2) ) = 125um
Error is:
For test 3.3.5. (line 28) command position in XYZ is (7,6,0,0) and the result is(7,52, -0.12, -0,02). That makes a difference of (80 um, -120um, -20um).

LVV-T1598.comment:
During the execution, the hexapod presents various random faults. The
problem was solved by exchanging the cabling for all actuators.
See\href{https://jira.lsstcorp.org/browse/FRACAS-64}{~FRACAS-64} and
\href{https://jira.lsstcorp.org/browse/FRACAS-56}{FRACAS-56}.\\
Please find the details of these tests in the attached report. This is
the summary of the report:\\
\textless{}\textbf{Image Download Error}\textgreater Image Download
Error\textgreater{}\\
In summary:\\
"Basically, the fundamental requirements for Image Quality and Image
Quality correction, as well as operational requirement specifications,
all seem to be met satisfactorily without load. It is not expected to
change appreciably with the camera mounted on the Hexapod and Rotator,
but some more testing, for completion, will probably be done with the
load."

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.1 Positioning of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 23-24.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Test this with no performance payload and at a single elevation angle of zero degrees. Wait for 39s between movements.
script_results.expectedResult:
The position of the hexapod is able to be commanded and no software limits or limit switches are tripped.
The position of the hexapod is able to reach the commanded positions within the absolute accuracy specifications of 25um in Z, 125um in XY, 205x10-5deg in RXRY, and 1500x10-5deg in RZ.
script_results.actualResult:
The camera hexapod was measured with the laser tracker during the 32 movements.
From the attached report:
"The camera hexapod positioning mostly meets requirements. Except for some marginal outliers, the XY accuracy is 29um RMS and the RxRy angular accuracy is 0.0015Deg RMS both meeting specs. The Z positioning is 31um RMS, apparently not meeting the spec of 25um, but this is because the laser tracker resolution is roughly 30um (in fact, most likely all laser-tracker-based measurements are limited by this resolution value). The Rz requirement of positioning accuracy <0.015Deg has not been checked (tbd)."

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.2 Centers of Rotation of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 24-25.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Record pivot position through the EUI. Wait for 39s between movements.
script_results.expectedResult: The center of rotation is able to be moved.
script_results.actualResult:
From the attached report:
"The measured and predicted Y displacement for a commanded Rx rotation coincide to better than 35um. The data on COR -820400um (-820.4 on the plot) corresponding to pivot on rotator surface, is from March 2021. The data for COR -2758400um (-2758.4 on the plot) pivot at L1S1, is from March 2021 and June 2021 after the camera hexapod actuators refurbishing, both sets of data coincide well. So COR definition works as expected."

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.3 Cross-Talk Motion of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 25.
script_results.expectedResult: There is no cross-talk observed (actuator positioning errors and erroneous geometry are minimal).
script_results.actualResult: From the attached report: "(a) Using the data from the X and Y Translational Range measurements (LTS-206, 3.3.4) and (b) from Rx and Ry Rotational range measurements (LTS-206, 3.3.8), the camera hexapod translation range’s cross talk is shown to meet specs. All commanded moves reach the destination with the inactive dimensions’ residuals being <125um for X and Y and <25um for Z."

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.4 Radial (X and Y) Translational Range of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 25.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Only test at a zero degree elevation angle. Wait for 39s between movements.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod is capable of moving to the positions in the XY plane listed in the Acceptance Test Procedure.
script_results.actualResult: From the attached report: The camera hexapod translation range meets specs. All commanded values range within 125um.

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.6 Axial (Z) Translation Range of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 27.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Only test at a zero degree elevation angle. Wait for 39s between movements.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod is capable of moving to the positions in the Z plane listed in the Acceptance Test Procedure.
script_results.actualResult: From the attached report: "The camera hexapod Z translational range meets specs. Positions reached within 25um. This test was not done exactly as the Moog procedure says (+/-8.7mm) because of time constraints. Instead, we just extracted the data from the absolute accuracy test."

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.8 Rotational Range Around X-Axis (Tip) and Y-Axis (Tilt) of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 28-29.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Only test at a zero degree elevation angle. Wait for 39s between movements.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod is capable of moving to the positions in the RXRY plane listed in the Acceptance Test Procedure.
script_results.actualResult: From the attached report: "The camera hexapod rotational range meets specs. Positions reached within 0.0021Deg."

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.10 Rotation Range Around Z-Axis (Twist) of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 30.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Only test at a zero degree elevation angle. Wait for 39s between movements.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod is capable of moving to the positions in the RZ-axis listed in the Acceptance Test Procedure.
script_results.actualResult: From the attached report: "Never checked the full range because of time and not critical, so lower priority, TBD anyway."

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.12 Hexapod Repeatability of the LSST Hexapods-Rotato Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 31.
script_results.expectedResult: The repeatability is as good as the test equipment can capture. This means that the repeatability is limited by the resolution of the test equipment.
script_results.actualResult:
From the attached report:
"Table 5. Shows that translation repeatability tests meet specifications, [1] and [4]. Starting from hexapod position (0,0,0,0,0,0), repeatability testing moves of 50um in absolute mode, are executed to within the specs of <4um for Z moves and <20um for X and Y moves. Note that starting from any other hexapod position away from the zero, means a different setup for the Linear Gauges, so it is not practical to do, because of time."

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.13 Hexapod Absolute Accuracy of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 38-42.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Only test at a zero degree elevation angle. Wait for 39s between movements.
script_results.expectedResult: The accuracy of the hexapod is good enough to be consistently repeated. The accuracy of the hexapod is at least the following: 25um in Z, 125um in XY, 205x10-5deg in RXRY, and 1500x10-5deg in RZ.
script_results.actualResult:
Data for (b) assembled from positioning and maximum range data.
Hexapod Absolute Accuracy in Rz not measured.

From the attached report: "a) shows that the camera hexapod translation Absolute Accuracy meets specs. All commanded moves in X, Y or Z, are reached within the required specs of <25um for Z and <125um for X and Y. (b) shows that the Camera Hexapod Absolute Rotation Accuracy meets the specs. Commanded moves are reached within the required specs of 0.0021Deg for Rx, Ry, [4]. Unfortunately, a set of measurements of Rz, as defined in [2], is missing. Left behind because it isn’t a movement expected to be used in operation, so was given little priority."

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.16 Hexapod Radial (X and Y) and Axial (Z) Velocity Range and 3.3.17 Hexapod Rotational Velocity of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 43-44.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Only test this using synchronous mode. Wait for 39s between movements.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod velocity exceeds the 152um/s in XY and 0.0039deg/s in RXYRY and RZ requirements.
script_results.actualResult:
Though this point was not investigated separately the camera hexapod reached all positions in a timely manner with all actuators nearly at the same time.
Small movements as used for science operations take only a few seconds what is well with the time frame given to the hexapod to reach its position between two exposures of the camera.

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.18 Hexapod Heat Dissipation of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 44.
script_results.expectedResult: The current measured by the inductive current probes is calculated to meet the heat dissipation requirement.
script_results.actualResult: The heat dissipation was monitored through the temperature sensors at the actuators and all temperatures stayed with in the allowed limits during the test.

FAULTSTATE

script_results.actualResult:
For the safety interlock, press the E-top first, click the switch button of release interlock 2, release the E-stop, click the switch button of reset interlock. By doing this, we could put/ release the safety interlock. No clearError in software side is needed.

When we opened the hexapod GUI, there was the simulink error after hitting the systemReady command and entered the Fault state. We can use the clearError to leave the Fault state and do the state transitions.

script_results.description:
Section 3.1.1 of the attached Software Acceptance Test Procedure
Test Sequence #1 - Synchronous PositionSet and Move Commands

With the synchronous button enabled and in enabled/stationary state, send a positionSet command of (0um, 0um, 200um, 0 deg, 0 deg, 0 deg) using the EUI.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod doesn't move.
script_results.actualResult: We sent the positionSet command of (0um, 0um, 200um, 0 deg, 0 deg, 0 deg) only and the hexapod did not move.

script_results.description: With the synchronous button enabled and in enabled/stationary state, send a positionSet command of (2000um, -3500um, 200um, .01 deg, -.05deg, .002deg) using the EUI.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod doesn't move.
script_results.actualResult: We sent the positionSet command of (2000um, -3500um, 200um, .01 deg, -.05deg, .002deg) only and the hexapod did not move.

script_results.description: Send a move command using the EUI.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod moves to the last commanded position of (2000um, -3500um, 200um, .01 deg, -.05deg, .002deg) and the actuators complete the move at nearly the same time as seen on the motion complete lights on the telemetry screen.
script_results.actualResult: We saw the movement of hexapod with position (2000um, -3500um, 200um, .01 deg, -.05deg, .002deg) after hitting the move command. The final position is (1999um, -3500um, 200um, .01 deg, -.05deg, .002deg) on GUI. We saw a "1 um" difference in x position.

script_results.description:
Section 3.1.1 of the attached Software Acceptance Test Procedure
Test Sequence #2 - Pivot, PositionSet and Move Commands

In enabled/stationary state and at the last commanded position of (2000um, -3500um, 200um, .01 deg, -.05deg, .002deg), change the pivot point from the default location to (0,0,0) using the EUI.
script_results.expectedResult: The actuator positions do not change, but the hexapod position is (-407um, -3982um, 199um, 0.01deg, -0.05deg, 0.002deg)
script_results.actualResult:
The default pivot position is (0, 0, -2758400um). Change the pivot to (0, 0, 0) in the offline state (it can not be changed in the enabled state). The hexapod position is (-408um, -3982um, 199um, 0.01deg, -0.05deg, 0.002deg). The x position differs by 1 um from the case 11.

PS. The pivot value can only be changed in the offline state not enabled/stationary state. There will be a prompt window to complain the wrong state.

script_results.description: In the enabled/stationary state, send a positionSet command of (2000um, -3500um, 200um, .01 deg, -.05deg, .002deg) using the EUI.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod doesn't move.

At startup, confirm that the system starts in the Offline/PublishOnly state.
script_results.expectedResult: The rotator starts in the Offline/PublishOnly state.
script_results.actualResult: It is the Offline/PublishOnly state at startup.

script_results.description: Send an offline substate trigger of systemReady.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the Offline/Available substate.
script_results.actualResult: The system transited to Offline/Available substate.

script_results.description: Send an EnterControl trigger.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Offline/Available to Standby state.
script_results.actualResult: The system transited to Standby state.

script_results.description: Send a Start trigger.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Standby to Disabled state.
script_results.actualResult: The system transited to Disabled state.

script_results.description: Send an Enable trigger.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Disabled to Enabled state.
script_results.actualResult: The system transited to Enabled state.

script_results.description: Send a Disable trigger.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Enabled to Disabled state.
script_results.actualResult: The system transited to Disabled state.

script_results.description: Send a Standby trigger.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Disabled state to Standby state.
script_results.actualResult: The system transited to Standby state.

script_results.description: Send a exitControl trigger.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Standby state to Offline state.
script_results.actualResult: The system transited to Offline state.

script_results.description: Return to the Enabled state and trip the safety interlock switch.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions to Fault state.
script_results.actualResult: The system transited to Fault state.

script_results.description: Reset the safety interlock and send a ClearError trigger.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Fault state to Offline state
script_results.actualResult: We did not send the clearError. We used the mechanical switches to remove the interlock error. This is considered to be done.

script_results.expectedResult: A Drive Fault error event is created and the system transitions to Fault state.

script_results.expectedResult: A Following Error event is created and the system transitions to Fault state.

script_results.description: Activate an extension limit switch on one of the actuators by removing the limit switch cover and manually tripping.
script_results.expectedResult: An Extended Limit Switch error event is created and the system transitions into Fault state.

script_results.description: Activate a retraction limit switch on one of the actuators by removing the limit switch cover and manually tripping.
script_results.expectedResult: A Retracted Limit Switch error event is created and the system transitions into Fault state.

script_results.description: Unplug the Ethercat cable between the control PC and the first Copley XE2 drive.
script_results.expectedResult: An Ethercat Lost event is created and the system transitions to Fault state.

<conditional state>
FAULTSTATE

script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Standby to Disabled state.

script_results.description: Send an Enable trigger.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Disabled to Enabled state.

script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Enabled to Disabled state.

script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Disabled state to Standby state.

script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from Standby state to Offline state.

script_results.description: Return to the Enabled state and trip the safety interlock switch.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions to Fault state.

script_results.description: Reset the safety interlock and send a ClearError trigger.

The EUI, upon receiving the "clearError" trigger, transitions to StandbyState when it was in EnableState or DisableState before the error occurred.

script_results.description:
STARTING THE EUI

Double click the Hexapod GUI Viewer desktop icon on the computer.
  • This can be done on the Dell Management PC or another computer on the same network
script_results.expectedResult: A prompt to enter a password is shown.
script_results.actualResult:
Starting the EUI is done through X2GO and the terminal.
Ask IT to set it up for you and copy the EUI scripts in the latest version on your account.
CAVE: The logic of the limit switches changed. Only the latest version EUI version is working.
Use your personalized X2GO account to connect to hexrot.cp.lsst.org
Use your personalized IPA password to login into your account.
Open a terminal. Change the past to ~/Desktop/hexCntrlEui/bin
Start the EUI with: ./runCamHexEui

script_results.description:
Enter the password "lsst-vnc"
  • If the EUI isn't automatically up and running when the VNC opens, double click on the Hexapod-eGUI icon on the VNC viewer
script_results.expectedResult: The EUI is in the Offline State/PublishOnly substate and is able to publish through SAL but cannot receive commands.
script_results.actualResult: Included in the previous step.

script_results.description:
OFFLINESTATE/PUBLISHONLY -> OFFLINESTATE/AVAILABLESTATE
On the Main tab, select the "Offline SubState Cmd" field in the Commands to Send section, set the Offline SubState Triggers to "System Ready" and click on the Send Command button.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from the OfflineState/PublishOnly substate to the OfflineState/AvailableState substate.
script_results.actualResult: Substate changes as expected.

script_results.description:
SWITCHING TO DDS MODE
If the Command Source does not show DDS, go to the Parameters tab, select DDS under the Command Source and click the Set Cmd Source button.
Note: If the GUI is used after being set to DDS mode, the system will switch back the Command Source to GUI and ignore any DDS commands. The Command Source must show DDS in order to receive DDS commands.
script_results.expectedResult: The system is capable of receiving/responding to DDS commands.
script_results.actualResult: Control mode changes as expected. Note confirmed. Any command from the EUI changes the control back to the EUI. This must manually be changed to give control back to the DDS.

script_results.description:
OFFLINESTATE -> STANDBYSTATE
The system receives an enterControl State Transition command through DDS.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the StandbyState and is capable of receiving/responding to DDS commands.
script_results.actualResult: State changes as expected.

script_results.description:
STANDBYSTATE -> DISABLEDSTATE
From the StandbyState, send a start command through the DDS.
script_results.expectedResult:
The system transitions into DisabledState after receiving/responding to DDS command and the wrapper in the PXI real time controller looks for the configuration file.

If the configuration file is invalid or out of range, the system will transition into a Fault State
script_results.actualResult:
Here the range of the parameters in the configuration file.
This is working. State machine transitioned from StandbyState to DisableState without faulting.

script_results.description:
DISABLEDSTATE -> ENABLEDSTATE
From the DisabledState, send an enable state command through the DDS.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the EnabledState/Stationary substate, the motor drives are enabled, motor brakes are released and the system is capable of receiving/responding to DDS commands.
script_results.actualResult:
Substate changes as expected.
Motor drives are enabled.
Not sure if there are motor breaks. But if there are motor breaks they are released.
The system is capable of receiving/responding to DDS commands.

script_results.description:
FAULTSTATE
If a Fault occurs in any of the other states, the system will automatically transition to the Fault State. While in the Fault state, send a clearError command through the DDS.
Note: If the fault that occurs goes through the interlock system, reset the safety relay switch and send a clearError command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions back to the OfflineState/PublishOnly substate and is not capable of receiving/responding to DDS commands. (Go back to Step 3)
script_results.actualResult:
Yes, the system goes to FaultState when a fault occurs in one of the other states.

Yes, the FaultState can be cleared by sending a clearError command through the DDS if the fault condition does not exist anymore.

Deviation: The system transitions back to StandbyState and can be commanded from DDS again. No need to go back to step 3.

MOVE TEST
Section 3.1.2 of the attached Software Acceptance Test Procedure
Test Sequence #1 - Synchronous PositionSet and Move Commands
In enabled/stationary state, send a positionSet command of (0um, 0um, 200um, 0 deg, 0 deg, 0 deg, s).
script_results.testData: Deviation: Skip this step. positionSet and move command replaced by new move command. Now, the hexapod starts movement directly after receiving the command.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod does not move.

script_results.description: With the synchronous button enabled and in enabled/stationary state, send a positionSet command of (500um, -500um, 200um, 0.01deg, -0.015deg, 0deg).
script_results.testData: Deviation: Skip this step. positionSet and move command replaced by new move command. Now, the hexapod starts movement directly after receiving the command.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod does not move

script_results.description: With the hexapod in in enabled/stationary state sync=True and send the move command of (x= 500um,y= -500um, z=200um, u=0.01deg, v=-0.015deg, w=0deg).
script_results.expectedResult:
• The hexapod moves to (x= 500um,y= -500um, z=200um, u=0.01deg, v=-0.015deg, w=0deg)
  • Since the Hexapod is in synchronous mode, the actuators complete the move at nearly the same time.
script_results.actualResult:
The hexapod moved to the expected position and the results read from the EFD are:

INFO:Script:STOP- Camera Hexapod Integration Test -- LVV-T1600 Test Step 7
hex position
    500.05     -500.87      200.12        0.01       -0.01       -0.00

script_results.description: Record the corresponding DDS events that were generated.
script_results.expectedResult:
• The controllerState.enabledSubstate goes to MOVING_POINT_TO_POINT when the move begins and STATIONARY when the move ends.
  • An inPosition event is generated when the move is complete
script_results.actualResult:
Yes, the controllerState.enabledSubstate goes to MOVING_POINT_TO_POINT when the move begins and STATIONARY when the move ends.

The inPosition event was not generated.
Looking at the EFD, the EFD shows that only for actuator one a status is present.
Actuators 2-6 always present the status zero.
Assuming that the information from all six actuators is needed, the inPosition event is not generated because of missing information on actuators 2-6.

script_results.actualResult: Thermal sensors were not present during the tests. See step 9.

script_results.description:
STARTING THE EUI

Double click the Hexapod GUI Viewer desktop icon on the computer.
  • This can be done on the Dell Management PC or another computer on the same network
script_results.expectedResult: A prompt to enter a password is shown.
script_results.actualResult: Deviation: We are using X2go now

script_results.description:
Enter the password "lsst-vnc"
  • If the EUI isn't automatically up and running when the VNC opens, double click on the Hexapod-eGUI icon on the VNC viewer
script_results.expectedResult: The EUI is in the Offline State/PublishOnly substate and is able to publish through SAL but cannot receive commands.

script_results.description:
OFFLINESTATE/PUBLISHONLY -> OFFLINESTATE/AVAILABLESTATE
On the Main tab, select the "Offline SubState Cmd" field in the Commands to Send section, set the Offline SubState Triggers to "System Ready" and click on the Send Command button.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from the OfflineState/PublishOnly substate to the OfflineState/AvailableState substate.

script_results.description:
SWITCHING TO DDS MODE
If the Command Source does not show DDS, go to the Parameters tab, select DDS under the Command Source and click the Set Cmd Source button.
Note: If the GUI is used after being set to DDS mode, the system will switch back the Command Source to GUI and ignore any DDS commands. The Command Source must show DDS in order to receive DDS commands.
script_results.expectedResult: The system is capable of receiving/responding to DDS commands.

script_results.description:
OFFLINESTATE -> STANDBYSTATE
The system receives an enterControl State Transition command through DDS.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the StandbyState and is capable of receiving/responding to DDS commands.

script_results.description:
STANDBYSTATE -> DISABLEDSTATE
From the StandbyState, send a start command through the DDS.
script_results.expectedResult:
The system transitions into DisabledState after receiving/responding to DDS command and the wrapper in the PXI real time controller looks for the configuration file.

If the configuration file is invalid or out of range, the system will transition into a Fault State
script_results.actualResult: Yes, the configuration was correctly loaded. No invalid configuration file was tested.

script_results.description:
DISABLEDSTATE -> ENABLEDSTATE
From the DisabledState, send an enable state command through the DDS.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the EnabledState/Stationary substate, the motor drives are enabled, motor brakes are released and the system is capable of receiving/responding to DDS commands.

script_results.description:
FAULTSTATE
If a Fault occurs in any of the other states, the system will automatically transition to the Fault State. While in the Fault state, send a clearError command through the DDS.
Note: If the fault that occurs goes through the interlock system, reset the safety relay switch and send a clearError command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions back to the OfflineState/PublishOnly substate and is not capable of receiving/responding to DDS commands. (Go back to Step 3)

STARTING THE EUI

Connect to the "hexrot"- virtual machine (https://vcenter.cp.lsst.org/ui/webconsole.html?vmId=vm-11015&vmName=hexrot-vm01.cp.lsst.org&numMksConnections=0&serverGuid=061cc04f-9571-4243-81e1-e90822bb0f30&locale=en-US)using your IPA/VPN credentials.

Change to the folder

cd /rubin/hexapod/build/

Start the EUI with the command:

./runCamHexEui

for the camera and the M2 hexapod, respectively.
script_results.expectedResult: The EUI is in the Offline State/PublishOnly substate and is able to publish through SAL but cannot receive commands.

script_results.description:
Transition from OFFLINE State/Publish Only Substate to OFFLINE State/Available Substate.

On the Main tab, select the Offline SubState Command radio button field in the Commands to Send section.
Then, set the Offline SubState Triggers to System Ready. 
Finally, click on the Send Command button.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions from the OfflineState/PublishOnly substate to the OfflineState/AvailableState substate and the Command Source says eGUI.
script_results.actualResult: Successfully transitioned to the OfflineState/AvailableState substate.

script_results.description:
Transition from OFFLINE State to STANDBY State.


On Commands to Send, select the State Commands radio button.

On State Triggers, scroll and select Enter Control.

Finally, click on the Send Command button.


The Hexapod should go to STANDBY state.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions to the Standby state and the primary state display box at the top of the Main says Standby state.
script_results.actualResult: The system transitioned successfully to the standbyState.

script_results.description:
Transition from STANDBY State to DISABLED State.


On Commands to Send, select the State Commands radio button.

On State Triggers, scroll and select the Start option.

Click on the Send Command button.


The Hexapod should go to DISABLED state.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into DISABLED State and the current configuration parameters are maintained from the default parameters or from the previous DDS start command.
script_results.actualResult: The system transitioned successfully to the disabledState.

script_results.description:
Transition from DISABLED State to ENABLED State.

On Commands to Send, select the State Commands radio button.

On State Triggers, scroll and select the Enabled option.

Click on the Send Command button.

The Hexapod should go to ENABLED state.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the ENABLED State/Stationary sub-state, the motor drives are enabled and motion can be commanded.
script_results.actualResult: The system transitioned successfully to the enabledState.

script_results.description:
<conditional state>

Recovering from a FAULT State

If a fault occurs in any of the other states, the system will automatically transition to the FAULT State.
While in the Fault state, select the clearError option in the State Triggers option list. Then, click on the Send Command button.

Note: If the fault that occurs goes through the interlock system, reset the safety relay switch and send a clearError command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions back to the STANDBY state. (Go back to Step 8)

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.1 Positioning of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 23-24.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Depending on the configuration, this test is with no performance payload or ComCam installed. The test is at a single elevation angle of zero degrees. The tester monitors the temperature using the EFD.
script_results.expectedResult:
The position of the hexapod is able to be commanded, and no software limits or limit switches are tripped.
The position of the hexapod is able to reach the commanded positions within the absolute accuracy specifications of 25um in Z, 125um in XY, 205x10-5deg in RXRY, and 1500x10-5deg in RZ.
script_results.actualResult:
The test is successfully executed, considering the precision of the laser tracker.
Details results are in cam.Hex.verif_06072021_30-31032022_v4.xls
LVV-18480 LTS-206-REQ-0087-V-02: 3.3.1_2 Positioning - LSST Re-verification

LVV-18479  LTS-206-REQ-0086-V-02: 3.3.1_1 Positioning - LSST Re-verification

Note: This requirement intends to ensure we can move in all directions and rotate simultaneously.
The required functionality was successfully tested by using 32 moves suggested by the vendor MOOG.
The code can be found at the end of https://github.com/lsst-sitcom/notebooks_vandv/blob/develop/notebooks/proj_sys_eng/sitcom_integration/LVV-T1598-CamHex_functional_re-verif.ipynb?short_path=7159b71

The plot from the EFD shows that we reached combined translation and rotation positions as expected.

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.16 Hexapod Radial (X and Y) and Axial (Z) Velocity Range and 3.3.17 Hexapod Rotational Velocity of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 43-44.
script_results.testData: Deviation: Only test this using synchronous mode. Wait for 39s between movements.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod velocity exceeds 152um/s in XY and 0.0039deg/s in RXYRY and RZ requirements.
script_results.actualResult:
• Speed in Z from 8.7.2022:  15460 um in 40 sec = 387um/s. This is twice the expected speed.
  • Since all six legs are involved in a movement in Z, the speed in X and Y can be assumed to be the same.
  • Rotation around RX 0.3deg in 19s = 0.015deg/s. This is about four times the speed required.
  • Since all legs move at the same speed, RX, RY and RX rotations are assumed to happen at the same speed.

script_results.description: Follow 3.3.18 Hexapod Heat Dissipation of the LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure, Sheet 44.
script_results.expectedResult: The current measured by the inductive current probes is calculated to meet the heat dissipation requirement.
script_results.actualResult:
The heat dissipation was monitored during all tests by using the temperature sensors at the actuators (part of the Environmental Sensor Suite (ESS)).
The temperature was at all times in the allowed range, even when we did various consecutive long moves or many (~1500) small moves to simulate an observing night. --> passed

Deviation: Determine where the original pivot point is before sending a pivot command of (0, 0, 0).
Record any offset commands necessary to test before sending the move command.
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod moves to the commanded position

script_results.description: In the enabled/stationary state, send a pivot command of (0,0,0).
script_results.expectedResult: The actuator positions do not change but the hexapod position changes to account for the new pivot point.

script_results.description: In the enabled/stationary state, send again the move command of (x=2000um, y=-3500um, z=200um, u=0.01deg, v=-0.05deg, w=0.002deg,sync=true)
script_results.testData: Deviation: Record any offset commands necessary to test before sending the move command.
script_results.expectedResult: Confirm the hexapod moves to the commanded position and the actuators change position to account for the new pivot point. Position values in the EFD appear different.

script_results.description: Wait 39s.

CONFIGURE LIMITS TEST
Section 3.1.2 of the attached Software Acceptance Test Procedure
Test Sequence #6 - configureLimits Command
In enabled/stationary state, send a configureLimits command of (12000um, -1000um, 1000um, 0.1, -0.1, 0.05)
script_results.testData: Deviation: Skip complete test. This test uses an obsolete command. The configuration is now done before and should not be changed this state
script_results.expectedResult: The command is rejected for being outside acceptable limits.

script_results.description: In enabled/stationary state, send a configureLimits command of (1000um, -1000um, 1000um, 0.1, -0.1, 0.05)
script_results.expectedResult: The command is accepted.

script_results.description: In enabled/stationary state, send a positionSet command of (1200um, 0um, 200um, 0deg, 0deg, 0deg)
script_results.expectedResult: The command is rejected for being outside of range limits

script_results.description: In enabled/stationary state, send a positionSet command of (990um, 990um, 200um, 0deg, 0deg, 0deg)
script_results.expectedResult: The command is rejected for being outside of range limits.

script_results.description: In enabled/stationary state, send a positionSet command of (500um, 500um, 200um, 0deg, 0.1 deg, 0.01deg)
script_results.expectedResult: The command is accepted.

script_results.description: Send a move command.
script_results.expectedResult: The previously accepted command is executed.

script_results.description: Record the DDS events that were generated.
script_results.expectedResult: The change is reflected in the settingsApplied event and the EUI.

script_results.description:
CONFIGURE ACCELERATION TEST
Section 3.1.2 of the attached Software Acceptance Test Procedure
Test Sequence #7 - configureAcceleration Command
In enabled/stationary state, at a position of (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0) with the velocity and acceleration values set to their nominal values, send a positionSet command of (0um, 0um, 4900um, 0 deg, 0 deg, 0 deg, s).
script_results.testData: Deviation: Skip complete test. This test uses an obsolete command. The configuration is now done before and should not be changed this state
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod doesn't move.

script_results.description: Send a move command.
script_results.expectedResult: The move takes approximately 9 seconds to complete.

script_results.description: Send a configureAcceleration command of 1000.
script_results.expectedResult: Confirm command is rejected for being outside of acceptable limits.

script_results.description: Send a configureAcceleration command of 100.
script_results.expectedResult: The command is accepted.

script_results.description: In enabled/stationary state, send a postionSet command of (0um, 0um, 0um, 0 deg, 0 deg, 0 deg, s).
script_results.expectedResult: The hexapod doesn't move.

script_results.description: Send a move command.
script_results.expectedResult: It takes approximately 13 seconds to complete the commanded move with the reduced acceleration value.

script_results.description: Send a configureAcceleration command of 500 to return the acceleration limit to its nominal value.
script_results.expectedResult: The command is accepted.

script_results.description: Record the corresponding DDS events that were generated.
script_results.expectedResult: The change is reflected in the settingsApplied event and the EUI.

script_results.description:
CONFIGURE VELOCITY TEST
Section 3.1.2 of the attached Software Acceptance Test Procedure
Test Sequence #8 - configureVelocity Command
In enabled/stationary state, at a position of (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0), send a configureVelocity command of (10000, .01, 100, .01).
script_results.testData: Deviation: Skip complete test. This test uses an obsolete command. The configuration is now done before and should not be changed this state
script_results.expectedResult: This command is rejected for being outside of acceptable limits.

script_results.description: In enabled/stationary state, send a configureVelocity command of (100, .01, 200, .01).
script_results.expectedResult: This command is accepted.

script_results.description: In enabled/stationary state, send a positionSet command of (0, 0um, 2000um, 0 deg, 0 deg, 0 deg, s).
script_results.expectedResult: The command is accepted

script_results.description: Send a move command.
script_results.expectedResult: It takes approximately 20 seconds to complete the commanded move.

script_results.description: In enabled/stationary state, send a configureVelocity command of (100, .01, 100, .01).
script_results.expectedResult: This command is accepted.

script_results.description: In enabled/stationary state, send an offset command of (0, 0um, 2000um, 0 deg, 0 deg, 0 deg).
script_results.expectedResult: This command is accepted

script_results.description: Send a move command.
script_results.expectedResult: It takes approximately 40 seconds to complete the commanded move.

script_results.description: Record the corresponding DDS events that were generated:
script_results.expectedResult: The change is reflected in the settingsApplied event and the EUI.

script_results.description:
Section 3.3.2 of the attached Software Acceptance Test Procedure Hexapod Action on State Commands
In the Offline/PublishOnly state, send all commands
script_results.expectedResult: There is no change and command is rejected.

script_results.description: In the Offline/Available state, send an enterControl command
script_results.expectedResult: The system enters the Standby state.

script_results.description: In the Standby state, send any command except start or exitControl
script_results.expectedResult: There is no change and command is rejected.

script_results.description: In the Standby state, send an exitControl command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the Offline/Available state.

script_results.description: In the Standby state, send a start command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the Disabled state.

script_results.description: In the Disabled state, send any command except for the enabled or standby command.
script_results.expectedResult: There is no change and the command is rejected.

script_results.description: In the Disabled state, send the standby command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the Standby state.

script_results.description: In the Disabled state, send the enable command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the Enabled/Stationary state.

script_results.description: In the Enabled/Stationary state, send either the enterControl command, exitControl command, start command, clearError command, or enable command.
script_results.expectedResult: There is no change and command is rejected.

script_results.description: In the Enabled/Stationary state, send a disable command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into Disabled state.

script_results.description: In the Fault state, send any command except the clearError command.
script_results.expectedResult: There is no change and command is rejected.

script_results.description: In the Fault state, send the clearError command.
script_results.expectedResult: The system transitions into the Offline/PublishOnly state.

script_results.description:
Section 4 of the attached Software Acceptance Test Procedure
In the Enabled/Stationary state, unplug a motor encoder cable for one of the actuators.
script_results.expectedResult: A Drive Fault error event is created and the system transitions to Fault state.

script_results.description: In the Enabled/Stationary state, unplug a linear encoder cable for one of the actuators.
script_results.expectedResult: A Drive Fault error event is created and the system transitions to Fault state.

script_results.description: Unplug a motor power cable from one of the actuators and command a Move.
script_results.expectedResult: A Following Error event is created and the system transitions to Fault state.

script_results.description: Activate an extension limit switch on one of the actuators by removing the limit switch cover and manually tripping.
script_results.expectedResult: An Extended Limit Switch error event is created and the system transitions into Fault state.

script_results.description: Activate a retraction limit switch on one of the actuators by removing the limit switch cover and manually tripping.
script_results.expectedResult: A Retracted Limit Switch error event is created and the system transitions into Fault state.

script_results.description: Unplug the Ethercat cable between the control PC and the first Copley XE2 drive.
script_results.expectedResult: An Ethercat Lost event is created and the system transitions to Fault state.

LVV-T1598.name: Camera Hexapod Hardware Functional Re-Verification
LVV-T1598.objective:
The objective of this test case is to re-verify the functional
requirements of the camera hexapod\textquotesingle s hardware after
shipment from the vendor\textquotesingle s facility to the Summit, as
defined in \citeds{LTS-206}.\\
This test case will only exercise the functionality that was executed
previously and meets the following criteria:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  It only requires the camera hexapod to be operable
\item
  Only requires the vendor\textquotesingle s EUI software and hardware
  via local control
\item
  Requires a laser tracker, mechanical gauges, induction current probe,
  temperature sensors
\item
  This test case can be executed with or without the camera rotator to
  be loaded with the camera simulated mass or actual camera hardware.\\
  \strut \\
\end{itemize}

The hardware functional requirements were previously verified during the
test campaign by the vendor at the vendor\textquotesingle s facility and
accepted by LSST during the Factory Acceptance Test review.\\
The test procedure used during the vendor\textquotesingle s acceptance
testing is the \emph{LSST Hexapods-Rotator Acceptance Test Procedure}
which is attached to this test case.\\
The test steps of this test case reference the vendor\textquotesingle s
acceptance test procedure for the details on how to perform the test.\\
The reference to the vendor\textquotesingle s acceptance test procedure
is included to perform the test similarly as it was performed
previously.\\
There are also deviations to the vendor\textquotesingle s acceptance
test procedure included in the test cases.\\
This became necessary due to the differences in the verification
configuration and deviations to requirements granted to the vendor by
Rubin.\\
\strut \\
See the attached \emph{LSST Rotator Hexapod\textquotesingle s Manual}
for more information on how to operate the hexapod.

LVV-T1599.name: Camera Hexapod Software Functional Re-verification
LVV-T1599.objective:
The objective of this test case is to re-verify the functional
requirements of the camera hexapod\textquotesingle s software after the
shipment of the hardware from the vendor\textquotesingle s facility to
the Summit, as defined in \citeds{LTS-206} and \citeds{LTS-160}.\\
This test case will only exercise the functionality that was executed
previously and meets the following criteria:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  It only requires the camera hexapod to be operable
\item
  It only requires testing of the synchronous mode

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \textbf{Asynchronous mode is not a standard mode of operation}
  \end{itemize}
\item
  Only requires the vendor\textquotesingle s EUI software and hardware
  via local control

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    It does \textbf{NOT} require integration with SAL
  \end{itemize}
\item
  This test case can be executed with or without the camera rotator to
  be loaded with the camera simulated mass or actual camera hardware.
\end{itemize}

The software functional requirements were previously verified during the
test campaign by the vendor at the vendor\textquotesingle s facility and
accepted by LSST during the Factory Acceptance Test review.\\
The test procedure used during the vendor\textquotesingle s acceptance
testing is the \emph{LSST Hexapods-Rotator Software Acceptance Test
Procedure} which is attached to this test case.\\
The test steps of this test case are taken directly from that document
in order to perform the test in a similar way as was performed
previously. The test steps include changes noted by the vendor.\\
\strut \\
See the attached \emph{LSST Hexapod Operator\textquotesingle s Manual}
for more information on how to operate the hexapod.

LVV-T1600.name: Integration of Camera Hexapod with SAL
LVV-T1600.objective:
The objective of this test case is to re-verify the functional
requirements of the camera hexapod\textquotesingle s software, after
shipment of the hardware from the vendor\textquotesingle s facility to
the Summit, as defined in \citeds{LTS-206} and \citeds{LTS-160}. This test case will only
exercise the functionality that was executed previously and meets the
following criteria:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Only requires the use of Russell\textquotesingle s code to replace
  MOOG\textquotesingle s middleware code
\item
  Only requires the camera hexapod to be operable
\item
  Only requires command through the CSC after the cRIO is switched from
  GUI mode to DDS mode
\item
  Only requires testing of the synchronous mode

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \textbf{Asynchronous mode is not a standard mode of operation}
  \end{itemize}
\item
  This test case can be executed with or without the camera rotator to
  be loaded with the camera simulated mass or actual camera hardware
\end{itemize}

The software functional requirements were previously verified during the
test campaign by the vendor at the vendor\textquotesingle s facility and
accepted by LSST during the Factory Acceptance Test review. The test
procedure used during the vendor\textquotesingle s acceptance testing is

which is attached to this test case. The test steps of this test case
are derived from the same procedure, but the order of the steps have
been changed to reflect the \emph{Proposal of Hexapod Test~on Dec.
2019~}Confluence page which can be found linked in the Traceability
